storyContent.tagHTML: The Dawn of a New Era

Towards the end of the third era (Ärä) of our current cosmic cycle, nature, which had always provided for humanity, began to decline. During this time of change, a wise leader named Kulkar Näbhiräyä and his wife, Queen Marudevi, had a son named Rishabh. As Rishabh grew, the struggle for survival among people intensified.

A visionary thinker, Rishabh taught people how to cultivate crops, cook food, build houses, and make tools, ushering in the age of civilization. He established the institution of marriage and became the first acknowledged ruler, King Rishabhadev. He had 100 sons, including the mighty Bharat (after whom India is named) and the strong Bähubali, and two daughters, Brähmi (who developed the art of writing) and Sundari (an expert in mathematics).

One day, Rishabhadev witnessed a dancer suddenly collapse and die. This profound event made him realize the impermanent nature of everything. He decided to renounce his kingdom in search of lasting happiness, dividing his lands among his sons and becoming a monk. Four thousand followers joined him.

As a monk, Rishabhadev was absorbed in meditation. However, his followers didn't know how to live without his guidance. To teach them the proper way for a monk to receive food, he began going for alms. But people, seeing their former king, offered him jewels and palaces, not realizing he needed food. This led him to fast for 400 continuous days.

Finally, his great-grandson Shreyäns realized what was needed and offered him sugarcane juice, breaking the long fast. This day is now celebrated as Akshay-tritiya. After years of austerities, Rishabhadev attained Keval-jnän (omniscience). He established the four-fold religious order (Jain Sangh) and became the first Tirthankar of our era, also known as Ädinäth, the 'First Lord'.

events.title: A World of Simplicity
events.description: Humanity lives a simple life where nature provides all necessities. Society is led by tribal leaders called Kulkars.

events.title: Birth of Rishabh
events.description: Rishabh is born to the final Kulkar, Näbhiräyä, and his wife, Queen Marudevi, as the world begins to change.

events.title: Teaching the Arts
events.description: Rishabhadev teaches humanity the arts of agriculture, cooking, building, and crafts to create a stable society.

events.title: Founding of Society
events.description: He establishes the institution of marriage and becomes the first king, while his children excel in various arts and sciences.

events.title: A Glimpse of Impermanence
events.description: The sudden death of a court dancer makes Rishabhadev realize the fleeting nature of life, prompting him to renounce his kingdom.

events.title: The Long Fast
events.description: While trying to teach the proper way of accepting alms, no one offers him food, leading to a 400-day fast.

events.title: The First Alms
events.description: His great-grandson, Shreyäns, understands his need and offers him sugarcane juice, breaking the fast on the day now known as Akshay-tritiya.

events.title: Omniscience Attained
events.description: After years of penance, Rishabhadev attains Keval-jnän, perfect knowledge.

events.title: Founding the Tirth
events.description: He establishes the four-fold religious order (Jain Sangh) and becomes the first Tirthankar, also known as Ädinäth.

charactersData.name: Bhagawän Rishabhadev
charactersData.description: Also known as Ädinäth, he was the first Tirthankar of our era. He transitioned humanity from a nature-dependent life to a civilized society before renouncing it all to find ultimate truth.

charactersData.name: Bharat & Bähubali
charactersData.description: Rishabhadev's eldest sons. Bharat was a mighty ruler after whom India is said to be named. Bähubali was known for his immense strength.

charactersData.name: Brähmi & Sundari
charactersData.description: Rishabhadev's learned daughters. Brähmi is credited with developing the art of writing (the Brähmi script), and Sundari was an expert in mathematics.

charactersData.name: Näbhiräyä & Marudevi
charactersData.description: The parents of Rishabhadev and the last of the Kulkars, the leaders of humanity in the preceding era.

charactersData.name: Shreyäns
charactersData.description: Rishabhadev's great-grandson, who had the wisdom to understand that the fasting monk needed food and broke his 400-day fast by offering him sugarcane juice.

quizData.question: Who were the parents of Bhagawän Rishabhadev?
Rishabhadev is considered the first Tirthankar of which part of the time cycle?
What was the name of Rishabhadev's eldest son, after whom India is believed to be named?
Which of Rishabhadev's daughters is credited with developing the art of writing?
What event caused Rishabhadev to realize the impermanence of life and renounce his kingdom?
quizData.answer: Witnessing the sudden death of a court dancer.

quizData.question: Why did Rishabhadev have to fast for 400 days after becoming a monk?
quizData.answer: People did not understand how to give alms to a monk and offered him valuables instead of food.

quizData.question: Who finally broke Rishabhadev's long fast, and what did he offer?
quizData.answer: His great-grandson, Shreyäns, offered him sugarcane juice.

quizData.question: The day Rishabhadev broke his fast is celebrated as what festival?
What is the other name for Rishabhadev, meaning 'the First Lord'?
What is the name of the Jain austerity that commemorates Rishabhadev's long fast?

children.name: End of an era of natural bounty

graphicsData.title: Teaching Civilization
graphicsData.description: As the world changes, the visionary Rishabh teaches his people essential skills like farming and building, laying the foundation for modern society.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Rishabhadev demonstrating how to use a plow to a group of early humans.

graphicsData.title: The Moment of Truth
graphicsData.description: While watching a performance, King Rishabhadev is profoundly shaken when a dancer suddenly dies, forcing him to confront the reality of impermanence.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A king on his throne looking shocked as a dancer falls to the floor.

graphicsData.title: The First Attempt at Alms
graphicsData.description: After becoming a monk, Rishabhadev seeks alms, but his former subjects, not understanding, offer him gold and jewels instead of the food he needs.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A monk standing silently as people try to offer him chests of treasure.

graphicsData.title: The Sugarcane Offering
graphicsData.description: After 400 days of fasting, his great-grandson Shreyäns wisely offers him sugarcane juice, breaking the fast and establishing a tradition of pure offerings.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A young man respectfully offering a glass of juice to the fasting monk Rishabhadev.

graphicsData.title: The First Sermon
graphicsData.description: Having attained omniscience, Bhagawän Rishabhadev, now Ädinäth, delivers his first sermon, establishing the four-fold order of monks, nuns, and lay followers.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Rishabhadev sits in a divine assembly, preaching to a group that includes monks, nuns, and families.

graphicsData.title: Legacy of the Children
graphicsData.description: Rishabhadev's children carry on his civilizing mission. Brähmi develops the script for writing, while Bharat becomes a legendary ruler.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A split image showing a woman carving symbols onto a leaf and a king looking over a map.
